          performance.mark('gtm.start');
          (function (w, d, s, l, i) {
            w[l] = w[l] || [];
            w[l].push({ 'gtm.start': new Date().getTime(), event: 'gtm.js' });
            var f = d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0],
                j = d.createElement(s),
                dl = l != 'dataLayer' ? '&l=' + l : '';
            j.async = true;
            j.src = 'https://www.googletagmanager.com/gtm.js?id=' + i + dl;
            j.onload = function () {
              performance.mark('gtm.end');
              performance.measure('gtm', 'gtm.start', 'gtm.end');
            };
            f.parentNode.insertBefore(j, f);
        })(window, document, 'script', 'dataLayer', 'GTM-M36RG8PT');
        </script><head><meta charSet="utf-8"/><meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width"/><link rel="shortcut icon" href="https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/favicon.7bc3d920.ico"/><script>

        window.eventsToSend = window.eventsToSend || []
        window.eventsToSend.push({
          name: "page_rendering",
          timestamp: new Date().toISOString(),
          value: JSON.stringify({
            time: performance?.now()
          })
        })
      } catch (error) {
        console.error("Failed to push page render event:", error)
      }

Their goals range from espionage for technology advancement and disruption of critical infrastructure to for-profit theft of trade secrets and supporting a political agenda. You no longer have a malware problem, you have an adversary problem, and you must incorporate an intelligence-driven approach to your security strategy. \r\n \r\nDuring this CrowdCast, you will learn class="metadata Metadata_root__EZem9" data-cy="metadata"><h1 class="Heading_heading__3MAvZ Heading_h1__3k7S2 title Title_root__svkHQ">CrowdCasts Monthly: You Have an Adversary Problem</h1><div class="stats Stats_root__p_BoZ"><time dateTime="2013-10-16 14:09:38 UTC">Oct 16, 2013</time><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_weight-strong__yEO2S Text_secondary__EPWj0 Text_medium__rk8Tn Likes_root__WVQ1_ text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">6 likes</span><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_weight-strong__yEO2S Text_secondary__EPWj0 Text_medium__rk8Tn Likes_root__WVQ1_ text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">21,365<!-- --> <!-- -->views</span></div><div class="author Author_root___6Bx5"><a data-cy="author-link" class="Author_link___lVxw ellipsis" title="CrowdStrike" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike"><div class="Avatar_root__GNWHY" style="width:24px;height:24px;line-height:24px"><img class="Avatar_image__Bbtll" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/profile-photo-CrowdStrike-48x48.jpg?cb=1523357406" alt="CrowdStrike" loading="lazy" decoding="sync"/></div><span>CrowdStrike</span></a></div><div class="description Description_root__kt4uq Description_clamped__PaV_1"><div class="Description_wrapper__hYE9_"><p data-cy="document-description">You Have an Adversary Problem. Who&#x27;s Targeting You and Why? 
 
Nation-States, Hacktivists, Industrial Spies, and Organized Criminal Groups are attacking your enterprise on a daily basis. Their goals range from espionage for technology advancement and disruption of critical infrastructure to for-profit theft of trade secrets and supporting a political agenda. You no longer have a malware problem, you have an adversary problem, and you must incorporate an intelligence-driven approach to your security strategy. 
 
During this CrowdCast, you will learn how to:

    Incorporate Actionable Intelligence into your existing enterprise security infrastructure 
    Quickly understand the capabilities and artifacts of targeted attacked tradecraft 
    Gain insight into the motivations and intentions of targeted attackers
    Make informed decisions based off of specific threat intelligence
</p></div><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_primary__K25Gq Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Description_more__ChrRK" data-testid="button" aria-label="Read more" data-cy="read-more-button"><span>Read more</span></button></div></div><div class="MetadataToolbar_root__x4cNG metadata-toolbar" data-cy="slideshow-toolbar"><div Today’s Speakers
ADAM MEYERS |
VP, INTELLIGENCE
Recognized speaker, trainer, and intelligence expert with 15+ years
of cyber security industry experience
10 years in the DIB supporting US GOV customers on topics
ranging from wireless, pen testing, IR, and malware analysis

@ADAM_CYBER

2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

4

 " src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-320.jpg" loading="lazy"/></div></a><div class="" id=":R48p7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R48p7d6"></div></div><div class="SlidePreviews_previewContainer__Qn8CH"><a aria-describedby="key-moment-4" class="SlidePreviews_momentContainer__zhQyW" href="#5" id="slide-preview-4" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R4ap7d6:" popovertarget=":R4ap7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R4ap7d6"><span class="SlidePreviews_slideHeading__sTrgx slide-heading">5</span><div class="SlidePreviews_thumbnailContainer__QWeuK thumbnail-container" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540"><img class="SlidePreviews_thumbnail__6RNF6" alt="@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Adversaries are humans
Targeted Attackers:

WHO ARE THE
ADVERSARIES?

Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
They need to get in
They will likely need to move laterally

Spray and Pray (Prey):
They don’t care who they target
(sometimes what)
The more they compromise the
more they win
Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

CORSAIR
JACKAL?

Khlifa (XTnR3v0LT)

malicious activity, but also white hat
activity.

compromise databases at target
organizations.

Vertical | Company | Geo-Location | Customers

these adversaries

INTELLIGENCE-DRIVEN SECURITY
INTELLIGENCE| Making it Actionable

1
ACTIONALIZING INTELLIGENCE

Intelligence is diﬃcult to consume
Lots of information to keep straight
New data constantly ﬂowing in (possibly unvetted)

2

Security Operations need to change shis &amp; people

3

Actionable Intelligence

Pass down can’t possibly occur with all indicators

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-3-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-3-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/75/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-3-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-3-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide4" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-3" alt="@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

4

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/75/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide5" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-4" alt="@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Adversaries are humans
Targeted Attackers:

WHO ARE THE
ADVERSARIES?

Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
They need to get in
They will likely need to move laterally

Spray and Pray (Prey):
They don’t care who they target
(sometimes what)
The more they compromise the
more they win
Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

Between indicators

colludes with Anonymous
group XL3gi0n

20

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-20-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-20-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/75/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-20-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-20-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide21" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-20" alt="@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

INTELLIGENCE-DRIVEN SECURITY
INTELLIGENCE| Adversary-Centric

1

INTELLIGENCE

Understand the adversaries targeting your
Vertical | Company | Geo-Location | Customers

2

Build appropriate defenses to counter/detect
these adversaries

3

Perform other security practices from an
Adversary-centric perspective
Pen Testing (Red Team)
Security Operations Brieﬁngs
Log Review

INTELLIGENCE-DRIVEN SECURITY
INTELLIGENCE| Making it Actionable

1
ACTIONALIZING INTELLIGENCE

Intelligence is diﬃcult to consume
Lots of information to keep straight
New data constantly ﬂowing in (possibly unvetted)

2

Security Operations need to change shis &amp; people

3

Actionable Intelligence

Pass down can’t possibly occur with all indicators

2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd1lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd1lh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Cyphort">Cyphort</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">In the digital age, one of the most effective ways to gather data and information about a potential enemy state is by infiltrating their ranks with malware. This webinar takes a deep drive into advanced persistent threat attacks performed by nation states. We will discuss various actors, government sponsored hackers, such as Duke, Bear, and Panda. Then we will look at malware created, like Regin, Elise, Flame, Equation Group, Babar, OnionDuke, and Dark Hotel.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R11lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R11lh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-1" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R12lh7d6:" popovertarget=":R12lh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R12lh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/AustinTaylor8/threat-hunting-with-data-science"><span class="sr-only">Threat Hunting with Data Science</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:1" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Threat Hunting with Data Science</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Threat Hunting with Data Science for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd2lh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rbd2lh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd2lh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd2lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd2lh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/AustinTaylor8">Austin Taylor</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">After anomalous network traffic has been identified there can still be an abundance of results for an analyst to process. This presentation is for data scientist and network security professionals who want to increase the signal-to-noise.

Flare is a network analytic framework designed for data scientists, security researchers, and network professionals. Written in python, flare is designed for rapid prototyping and development of behavioral analytics. Flare comes with a collection of pre-built utility functions useful for performing feature extraction.

Using flare, we&#x27;ll walk through identifying Domain Generation Algorithms (DGA) commonly used in malware and how to reduce the dataset to a manageable amount for security professionals to process.

We&#x27;ll also explore flare&#x27;s beaconing detection which can be used with the output from popular Intrusion Detection System (IDS) frameworks.

More information on flare can be found at https://github.com/austin-taylor/flare

www.austintaylor.io

</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R12lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R12lh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime It also discusses applying machine learning and data science techniques to security. Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Cyber Kill Chain.pptx for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd5lh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rbd5lh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd5lh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd5lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd5lh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/VivekChauhan107">Vivek Chauhan</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The Cyber Kill Chain describes the typical stages of a cyberattack: reconnaissance, weaponization, delivery, exploitation, installation, command and control, and actions on objective. Organizations can use this framework to understand attacks and develop defenses. They can also correlate security information and management (SIEM) data to detect attacks corresponding to each stage. Recommendations for prevention and detection include threat intelligence, malware analysis, email security, intrusion detection, access management, and incident response planning. The Cyber Kill Chain provides a high-level view, while the MITRE ATT&amp;CK Framework details tactics and techniques, allowing comprehensive defenses.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R15lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R15lh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" data-cy="slideshow-title">Data Loss Prevention from Symantec</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Data Loss Prevention from Symantec for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd7lh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rbd7lh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd7lh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd7lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd7lh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/ArrowECSMarketing">Arrow ECS UK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Symantec Data Loss Prevention helps organizations address the serious problem of data loss by providing visibility into where sensitive data is located and how it is being used, enabling monitoring of data movement and detection of policy violations, and offering flexible options for protecting data and educating employees to prevent accidental or intentional data loss. Symantec is a leader in this field with the most highly rated products, largest customer base, and deepest expertise in helping customers improve security, comply with regulations, and reduce the costs of data breaches.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R17lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R17lh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-7" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R18lh7d6:" popovertarget=":R18lh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R18lh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/jorgeorchilles/adversary-emulation-and-the-c2-matrix"><span class="sr-only">Adversary Emulation and the C2 Matrix</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:7" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Adversary Emulation and the C2 Matrix" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/adversaryemulationc2matrix-orchilles-200226130448-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Adversary Emulation and the C2 Matrix" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/adversaryemulationc2matrix-orchilles-200226130448-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Adversary Emulation and the C2 Matrix</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Adversary Emulation and the C2 Matrix for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd8lh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rbd8lh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd8lh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd8lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd8lh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/jorgeorchilles">Jorge Orchilles</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Command and Control is one of the most important tactics in the MITRE ATT&amp;CK matrix as it allows the attacker to interact with the target system and realize their objectives. Organizations leverage Cyber Threat Intelligence to understand their threat model and adversaries that have the intent, opportunity, and capability to attack. Red Team, Blue Team, and virtual Purple Teams work together to understand the adversary Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures to perform adversary emulations and improve detective and preventive controls.

The C2 Matrix was created to aggregate all the Command and Control frameworks publicly available (open-source and commercial) in a single resource to assist teams in testing their own controls through adversary emulations (Red Team or Purple Team Exercises). Phase 1 lists all the Command and Control features such as the coding language used, channels (HTTP, TCP, DNS, SMB, etc.), agents, key exchange, and other operational security features and capabilities. This allows more efficient decision making when called upon to emulate and adversary TTPs.

It is the golden age of Command and Control (C2) frameworks. Learn how these C2 frameworks work and start testing against your organization to improve detective and preventive controls.

The C2 Matrix currently has 35 command and control frameworks documented in a Google Sheet, web site, and questionnaire format.

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1b4mUxa6cDQuTV2BPC6aA-GR4zGZi0ooPYtBe4IgPsSc/edit#gid=0

https://www.thec2matrix.com/matrix

https://ask.thec2matrix.com/

Learn how Red Teams and Blue Teams work together in virtual Purple Teams
Leverage Cyber Threat Intelligence to understand adversary tactics, techniques, and procedures
Perform adversary emulations in Red or Purple Team Exercises
Choose which command and control to use for the assessment to provide the most value
Measure and improve people, process, and technology</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R18lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R18lh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-8" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R19lh7d6:" popovertarget=":R19lh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R19lh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/red-team-framework/163164716"><span class="sr-only">Red Team Framework</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:8" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Red Team Framework" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/redteamframework-190812114352-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Red Team Framework" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/redteamframework-190812114352-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Red Team Framework</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Red Team Framework for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd9lh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rbd9lh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd9lh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd9lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd9lh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/JoeGrayCISSPISSMP">👀 Joe Gray</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Presented at the DEFCON27 Red Team Offensive Village on 8/10/19.

From the dawn of technology, adversaries have been present. They have ranged from criminal actors and curious children to - more modernly - nation states and organized crime. As an industry, we started to see value in emulating bad actors and thus the penetration test was born. As time passes, these engagements become less about assessing the true security of the target organization and more about emulating other penetration testers. Furthermore, these tests have evolved into a compliance staple that results in little improvement and increasingly worse emulation of bad actors.

In this presentation, we will provide a framework complementary to the Penetration Testing Execution Standard (PTES). This complementary work, the Red Team Framework (RTF), focuses on the objectives and scoping of adversarial emulation with increased focus on the perspective of the business, their threat models, and business models. The RTF borrows part of the PTES, adding emphasis on detection capabilities as well as purple team engagements. We believe this approach will better assist organizations and their defensive assets in understanding threats and building relevant detections.
</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R19lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R19lh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-9" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1alh7d6:" popovertarget=":R1alh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1alh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/building-an-info-sec-redteam/26841513"><span class="sr-only">Building an InfoSec RedTeam</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:9" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Building and maintaining a Red Team &amp; Penetration Testing Team as the driving force of the Security Organizational Structure</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1alh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1alh7d6"></div><div slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/SupriyaKumarMitraLoo">penetration Tester</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">1. Vulnerability assessment and penetration testing (VAPT) involves identifying security vulnerabilities in an organization&#x27;s network and systems through scanning and manual exploitation techniques. 
2. The process includes information gathering, scanning to detect vulnerabilities, analysis of vulnerabilities found, and penetration testing to manually exploit vulnerabilities.
3. The final report documents the findings by risk level, technical details of vulnerabilities discovered, and recommendations for remediation.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1blh7d6:" type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbddlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbddlh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Splunk">Splunk</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document is a presentation on threat hunting with Splunk. It discusses threat hunting basics, data sources for threat hunting, knowing your endpoint, and using the cyber kill chain framework. It outlines an agenda that includes a hands-on walkthrough of an attack scenario using Splunk&#x27;s core capabilities. It also discusses advanced threat hunting techniques and tools, enterprise security walkthroughs, and applying machine learning and data science to security.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1dlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1dlh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses red team penetration testing and modern cybersecurity risks. It provides an overview of red teaming, including thinking like a sophisticated attacker to uncover security weaknesses through external and internal network exploitation, web application attacks, and social engineering. The document notes that Indian organizations are at high risk of cyber attacks due to poor cyber defenses, lack of awareness, and internal threats. Mitigations include increasing cybersecurity education and budgeting.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1flh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses threat hunting techniques using Splunk, including an overview of threat hunting basics, data sources for threat hunting, and Lockheed Martin&#x27;s Cyber Kill Chain model. It provides examples of using endpoint data to hunt for threats across the kill chain by analyzing processes, communications, and file artifacts in a demo dataset. Advanced techniques discussed include hunting for SQL injection attacks and lateral movement.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1glh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" ATT&amp;CK</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save ATT&amp;CK Updates- Defensive ATT&amp;CK for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdhlh7d6:" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdhlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdhlh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Lex Crumpton leads MITRE&#x27;s defensive ATT&amp;CK efforts. In 2021, they added data sources and detections for monitoring processes interacting with LSASS.exe and detecting credential dumping tools. In 2022, they plan to add more detections and develop the Cyber Analytic Repository to share analytic knowledge. Crumpton invites attendees to learn more about defensive ATT&amp;CK on their website and contact them directly with any other questions.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1hlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1hlh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-17" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1ilh7d6:" popovertarget=":R1ilh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1ilh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/purple-team-exercises-grimmcon/236943108"><span class="sr-only">Purple Team Exercises - GRIMMCon</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:17" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Purple Team Exercises - GRIMMCon" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/purpleteamexercises-grimmcon-200715204424-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Purple Team Exercises - GRIMMCon" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/purpleteamexercises-grimmcon-200715204424-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Purple Team Exercises - GRIMMCon</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Purple Team Exercises - GRIMMCon for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdilh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rbdilh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdilh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdilh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdilh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/jorgeorchilles">Jorge Orchilles</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Offensive security and Ethical Hacking is about providing business value. One of the most efficient and effective ways to improve security is through Adversary Emulation Purple Team Exercises. Adversary Emulation is a type of ethical hacking engagement where the Red Team emulates how an adversary operates, leveraging the same tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), against a target organization. The goal of these engagements is to train and improve people, process, and technology. This is in contrast to a penetration test that focuses on testing technology and preventive controls. Adversary emulations are performed using a structured approach following industry methodologies and frameworks (such as MITRE ATT&amp;CK) and leverage Cyber Threat Intelligence to emulate a malicious actor that has the opportunity, intent, and capability to attack the target organization. Adversary Emulations may be performed in a blind manner (Red Team Engagement) or non-blind (Purple Team) with the Blue Team having full knowledge of the engagement. In this talk, we will cover how to run a high-value adversary emulation through a Purple Team Exercise.

https://www.scythe.io/library/threatthursday-apt33</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ilh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ilh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-18" aria-haspopup="dialog" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/incident-response-concepts/152858257"><span class="sr-only">INCIDENT RESPONSE CONCEPTS</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:18" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="INCIDENT RESPONSE aria-controls=":Rbdjlh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rbdjlh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdjlh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdjlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdjlh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/SylvainMartinez5">Sylvain Martinez</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This presentation looks at the core component of an Incident Response plan (NIST 800-61) as well as custom practical implementation framework developed by ELYSIUMSECURITY based on NIST and FIRST.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1jlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1jlh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-19" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1klh7d6:" popovertarget=":R1klh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1klh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/cyber-threat-hunting-with-phirelight/67747065"><span class="sr-only">Cyber Threat Hunting with Phirelight</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Cyber Threat Hunting with Phirelight</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" control and minimize the overall damage. These rare, but essential, breed of enterprise cyber defenders give proactive security a whole new meaning.

Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Adversary Emulation and Its Importance for Improving Security Posture in Orga... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdllh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rbdllh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdllh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdllh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdllh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/digitoktavianto">Digit Oktavianto</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses adversary emulation and its importance for improving security posture. It begins with an introduction to adversary emulation, comparing it to simulation. Adversary emulation involves closely mimicking the actual tactics, techniques, and procedures of a known adversary based on threat intelligence. The document outlines the benefits of adversary emulation, such as helping organizations test their defenses against the latest real-world threats. It also provides guidance on developing an adversary emulation plan, including researching a specific adversary and modeling their behaviors to design scenario-based tests that are executed sequentially.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1llh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1llh7d6"></div><div class="separator class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Tracking Noisy Behavior and Risk-Based Alerting with ATT&amp;CK</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Tracking Noisy Behavior and Risk-Based Alerting with ATT&amp;CK for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdplh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rbdplh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdplh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdplh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdplh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Haylee Mills, Splunk

Having ATT&amp;CK to identify threats, prioritize data sources, and improve security posture has been a huge step forward for our industry, but how do we actualize those insights for better detection and alerting? By shifting to observations of behavior over one-to-one direct alerts, noisy datasets become valuable treasure troves with ATT&amp;CK metadata. Additionally, we can begin to look at detection and threat hunting on behavior instead of users or systems. In this presentation, Haylee will discuss the shift in mindset and the nuts and bolts of detections that leverage this metadata in Splunk, but the concept can be applied with custom tools to any valuable security dataset.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1plh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1plh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf style="anchor-name:--popover-R1qlh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/NishaYadav177/footprinting-and-reconnaissance-232089619"><span class="sr-only">Footprinting and reconnaissance</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail reconnaissance</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" people.You will find amazing tools and techniques have a look</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1qlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-26" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1rlh7d6:" popovertarget=":R1rlh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1rlh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" It also covers typical DLP system architecture, approaches for data classification and identification, and some technical challenges. The document references DLP product websites and summarizes two research papers on using machine learning for automatic text classification to identify sensitive data for DLP systems.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1rlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1rlh7d6"></div><div class="separator RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes a CrowdStrike webinar on detecting advanced malware-free intrusions. It describes three speakers from CrowdStrike - Dmitri Alperovitch, Chris Scott, and Adam Meyers. The webinar then discusses how adversaries like China and various state-sponsored and criminal groups are adapting their tactics to evade detection, and how security teams must also adapt detection methods to focus on real-time monitoring rather than indicators of compromise. The webinar includes a case study of detecting a webshell attack in near real-time using CrowdStrike Falcon Host and concludes with a demonstration of its endpoint protection capabilities.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1tlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1tlh7d6"></div><div class="separator class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">In today’s threat environment, adversaries are constantly profiling and attacking your corporate infrastructure to access and collect your intellectual property, proprietary data, and trade secrets. Now, more than ever, Threat Intelligence is increasingly important for organizations who want to proactively defend against advanced threat actors.

While many organizations today are collecting massive amount of threat intelligence, are they able to translate the information into an effective defense strategy?

View the slides now to learn about threat intelligence for operational purposes, including real-world demonstrations of how to consume intelligence and integrate it with existing security infrastructure.

Learn how to prioritize response by differentiating between commodity and targeted attacks and develop a defense that responds to specific methods used by advanced attackers.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ulh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ulh7d6"></div></div></div></div><!--$--><div class="RelatedContent_root__29Np1"><div class="RelatedContent_wrapper__riU7l"><h2 class="Heading_heading__3MAvZ Heading_h2__f9yvs RelatedContent_title__QUhpL">More Related Content</h2><div class="bottom-recs BottomRecommendation_root__7aU9w"><h3 class="BottomRecommendation_title__SRj68">What&#x27;s hot<!-- --> <span class="BottomRecommendation_count__4HpLo">(<!-- -->20<!-- -->)</span></h3><div class="BottomRecommendationContent_root__2qm4_"><div class="mobile-recs"><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-0" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rgm9i7d6:" popovertarget=":Rgm9i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rgm9i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/red-team-framework/163164716"><span class="sr-only">Red Team Framework</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:0" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Red Team Framework" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/redteamframework-190812114352-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Red Team Framework" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/redteamframework-190812114352-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Red Team Framework</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Red Team Framework for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mgm9i7d6:" popovertarget=":R5mgm9i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mgm9i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mgm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mgm9i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/JoeGrayCISSPISSMP">👀 Joe Gray</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Presented at the DEFCON27 Red Team Offensive Village on 8/10/19.

From the dawn of technology, adversaries have been present. They have ranged from criminal actors and curious children to - more modernly - nation states and organized crime. As an industry, we started to see value in emulating bad actors and thus the penetration test was born. As time passes, these engagements become less about assessing the true security of the target organization and more about emulating other penetration testers. Furthermore, these tests have evolved into a compliance staple that results in little improvement and increasingly worse emulation of bad actors.

In this presentation, we will provide a framework complementary to the Penetration Testing Execution Standard (PTES). This complementary work, the Red Team Framework (RTF), focuses on the objectives and scoping of adversarial emulation with increased focus on the perspective of the business, their threat models, and business models. The RTF borrows part of the PTES, adding emphasis on detection capabilities as well as purple team engagements. We believe this approach will better assist organizations and their defensive assets in understanding threats and building relevant detections.
</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rgm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rgm9i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-1" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rh69i7d6:" popovertarget=":Rh69i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rh69i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/building-an-info-sec-redteam/26841513"><span class="sr-only">Building an InfoSec RedTeam</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:1" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Vapt life cycle for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mhm9i7d6:" popovertarget=":R5mhm9i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mhm9i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mhm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mhm9i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/SupriyaKumarMitraLoo">penetration Tester</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">1. Vulnerability assessment and penetration testing (VAPT) involves identifying security vulnerabilities in an organization&#x27;s network and systems through scanning and manual exploitation techniques. 
2. The process includes information gathering, scanning to detect vulnerabilities, analysis of vulnerabilities found, and penetration testing to manually exploit vulnerabilities.
3. The final report documents the findings by risk level, technical details of vulnerabilities discovered, and recommendations for remediation.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rhm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rhm9i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" for Threat Modelling purpose, which can be use for Adversary Emulation and Attack Defense. SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses red team penetration testing and modern cybersecurity risks. It provides an overview of red teaming, including thinking like a sophisticated attacker to uncover security weaknesses through external and internal network exploitation, web application attacks, and social engineering. The document notes that Indian organizations are at high risk of cyber attacks due to poor cyber defenses, lack of awareness, and internal threats. Mitigations include increasing cybersecurity education and budgeting.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rjm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" threat hunting, and Lockheed Martin&#x27;s Cyber Kill Chain model. It provides examples of using endpoint data to hunt for threats across the kill chain by analyzing processes, communications, and file artifacts in a demo dataset. data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save ATT&amp;CK Updates- Defensive ATT&amp;CK for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mkm9i7d6:" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mkm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mkm9i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Lex Crumpton leads MITRE&#x27;s defensive ATT&amp;CK efforts. In 2021, they added data sources and detections for monitoring processes interacting with LSASS.exe and detecting credential dumping tools. In 2022, they plan to add more detections and develop the Cyber Analytic Repository to share analytic knowledge. Crumpton invites attendees to learn more about defensive ATT&amp;CK on their website and contact them directly with any other questions.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rkm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rkm9i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-9" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rl69i7d6:" popovertarget=":Rl69i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rl69i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/purple-team-exercises-grimmcon/236943108"><span class="sr-only">Purple Team Exercises - GRIMMCon</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:9" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Purple Team Exercises - GRIMMCon" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/purpleteamexercises-grimmcon-200715204424-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Purple Team Exercises - GRIMMCon" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/purpleteamexercises-grimmcon-200715204424-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Purple Team Exercises - GRIMMCon</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Purple Team Exercises - GRIMMCon for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5ml69i7d6:" popovertarget=":R5ml69i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5ml69i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5ml69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5ml69i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/jorgeorchilles">Jorge Orchilles</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Offensive security and Ethical Hacking is about providing business value. One of the most efficient and effective ways to improve security is through Adversary Emulation Purple Team Exercises. Adversary Emulation is a type of ethical hacking engagement where the Red Team emulates how an adversary operates, leveraging the same tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), against a target organization. The goal of these engagements is to train and improve people, process, and technology. This is in contrast to a penetration test that focuses on testing technology and preventive controls. Adversary emulations are performed using a structured approach following industry methodologies and frameworks (such as MITRE ATT&amp;CK) and leverage Cyber Threat Intelligence to emulate a malicious actor that has the opportunity, intent, and capability to attack the target organization. Adversary Emulations may be performed in a blind manner (Red Team Engagement) or non-blind (Purple Team) with the Blue Team having full knowledge of the engagement. In this talk, we will cover how to run a high-value adversary emulation through a Purple Team Exercise.

https://www.scythe.io/library/threatthursday-apt33</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rl69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rl69i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div popovertarget=":Rlm9i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rlm9i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mmm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mmm9i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/digitoktavianto">Digit Oktavianto</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses adversary emulation and its importance for improving security posture. It begins with an introduction to adversary emulation, comparing it to simulation. Adversary emulation involves closely mimicking the actual tactics, techniques, and procedures of a known adversary based on threat intelligence. The document outlines the benefits of adversary emulation, such as helping organizations test their defenses against the latest real-world threats. It also provides guidance on developing an adversary emulation plan, including researching a specific adversary and modeling their behaviors to design scenario-based tests that are executed sequentially.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rmm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rmm9i7d6"></div><div class="separator CTS CERT-GOV-MD</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses penetration testing and ethical hacking. Attacks</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:15" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a ATT&amp;CK</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:16" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Tracking Noisy Behavior and Risk-Based Alerting with ATT&amp;CK</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Tracking Noisy Behavior and Risk-Based Alerting with ATT&amp;CK for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mom9i7d6:" popovertarget=":R5mom9i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mom9i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mom9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mom9i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Haylee Mills, Splunk

Having ATT&amp;CK to identify threats, prioritize data sources, and improve security posture has been a huge step forward for our industry, but how do we actualize those insights for better detection and alerting? By shifting to observations of behavior over one-to-one direct alerts, noisy datasets become valuable treasure troves with ATT&amp;CK metadata. Additionally, we can begin to look at detection and threat hunting on behavior instead of users or systems. In this presentation, Haylee will discuss the shift in mindset and the nuts and bolts of detections that leverage this metadata in Splunk, but the concept can be applied with custom tools to any valuable security dataset.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rom9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rom9i7d6"></div><div class="separator Attack</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes a CrowdStrike webinar on detecting advanced malware-free intrusions. It describes three speakers from CrowdStrike - Dmitri Alperovitch, Chris Scott, and Adam Meyers. The webinar then discusses how adversaries like China and various state-sponsored and criminal groups are adapting their tactics to evade detection, and how security teams must also adapt detection methods to focus on real-time monitoring rather than indicators of compromise. The webinar includes a case study of detecting a webshell attack in near real-time using CrowdStrike Falcon Host and concludes with a demonstration of its endpoint protection capabilities.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rgmai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rgmai7d6"></div><div class="separator class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">In today’s threat environment, adversaries are constantly profiling and attacking your corporate infrastructure to access and collect your intellectual property, proprietary data, and trade secrets. Now, more than ever, Threat Intelligence is increasingly important for organizations who want to proactively defend against advanced threat actors.

While many organizations today are collecting massive amount of threat intelligence, are they able to translate the information into an effective defense strategy?

View the slides now to learn about threat intelligence for operational purposes, including real-world demonstrations of how to consume intelligence and integrate it with existing security infrastructure.

Learn how to prioritize response by differentiating between commodity and targeted attacks and develop a defense that responds to specific methods used by advanced attackers.</span></div></div><div RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Michael Saylor is the executive director of Cyber Defense Labs at UT Dallas. The document discusses current cyber security trends and emerging threats. Recent trends in 2013 included an increase in attacks with web and social engineering components as well as politically motivated DDoS attacks. Mobile devices and applications are increasingly being targeted, as are advanced persistent threats from groups like China&#x27;s APT1. Emerging threats discussed include the potential for increased cyber crime and terrorism from groups funded by drug cartels and foreign states. The document recommends best practices for organizations like user education, monitoring, encryption, and frequent security assessments.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rhmai7d6:" popover="auto" security departments. But the technology and motivation behind APTs has changed significantly since the introduction of Stuxnet, continuing to evolve rapidly to avoid detection. 
In this special Dark Reading presentation, a leading expert on the origins and directions of APTs will discuss the changing nature of these sophisticated threats – and how you can prepare your enterprise security environment to detect and mitigate these complex and dangerous attacks.

aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mjmai7d6:" popovertarget=":R5mjmai7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mjmai7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mjmai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mjmai7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Radware">Radware</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Prepared by Radware’s Emergency Response Team (ERT), 2012 Global Application and Network Security Report highlights server-based botnets and encrypted layer attacks as just two of the new attack tools challenging organizations during DDoS attacks. Most recently, these tactics were leveraged by perpetrators in the attacks against U.S. financial institutions that have been ongoing since September 2012.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rjmai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rjmai7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-7" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rk6ai7d6:" popovertarget=":Rk6ai7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rk6ai7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/trend-micro-is-your-cloud-secure/16776407"><span class="sr-only">Trend Micro - is your cloud secure</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:7" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Trend Micro - is your cloud secure</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Trend Micro - is your cloud secure for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mk6ai7d6:" popovertarget=":R5mk6ai7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mk6ai7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mk6ai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mk6ai7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Kappadata">Kappa Data </a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses the need for organizations to have a smart protection strategy to secure their cloud environments from cyber threats. It notes that threats are becoming more challenging due to trends like cloud/virtualization, consumerization, and the actions of employees. An effective strategy uses global threat intelligence from multiple sources to detect both known and unknown threats. It advocates for network-wide detection, custom sandboxes for analysis, and automated security updates. The strategy aims to provide advanced, targeted protection while remaining simple to manage and deploy.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rk6ai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rk6ai7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">KASPERSKY SECURITY BULLETIN 2013</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mkmai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mkmai7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Kappadata">Kappa Data </a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Once again, it’s time for Kaspersky to deliver our customary retrospective of the key events that have defined the threat landscape in 2013. Let’s start by looking back at the things we thought would shape the year ahead, based on the trends we observed in the previous year. </span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rkmai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rkmai7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-9" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rl6ai7d6:" popovertarget=":Rl6ai7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rl6ai7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/cb19-from-advanced-persistent-threats-to-advanced-persistent-manipulators-the-evolving-cyber-defense-battlefield-by-mei-nelson/204343930"><span class="sr-only">[CB19] From Advanced Persistent Threats to &quot;Advanced Persistent Manipulators&quot;...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:9" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="[CB19] From Advanced Persistent Threats to &quot;Advanced Persistent Manipulators&quot;..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/idefensemeinelsoncodeblue19slidedeck20191125public-191211072501-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img
